description: Enterprise techniques used by menuPass, ATT&CK group G0045 v1.3
name: menuPass (G0045)

techniques.comment: menuPass has used the Microsoft administration tool csvde.exe to export Active Directory data.[7]
menuPass executes commands using a command-line interface and reverse shell. The group has used a modified version of pentesting script wmiexec.vbs to execute commands.[4][7][8][10]
menuPass has used a global service provider's IP as a proxy for C2 traffic from a victim.[5][10]
menuPass has used a modified version of pentesting tools wmiexec.vbs and secretsdump.py to dump credentials.[7][8]
menuPass has compressed files before exfiltration using TAR and RAR.[4][7]
menuPass has encrypted files and information before exfiltration.[6]
menuPass has collected various files from the compromised computers.[6]
menuPass has collected data from remote systems by mounting network shares with net use and using Robocopy to transfer data.[4]
menuPass stages data prior to exfiltration in multi-part archives, often saved in the Recycle Bin.[4]

menuPass has used certutil in a macro to decode base64-encoded content contained in a dropper document attached to an email. The group has also used certutil -decode to decode files on the victim’s machine when dropping UPPERCUT.[9][10]
menuPass has used DLL search order hijacking.[4]
menuPass has used DLL side-loading to launch versions of Mimikatz and PwDump6 as well as UPPERCUT.[7][10]
A menuPass macro deletes files after it has decoded and decompressed them.[9][6]
menuPass has used key loggers to steal usernames and passwords.[6]

menuPass has been seen changing malicious files to appear legitimate. They have also renamed certutil and move it to a different location on system to avoid detection based on use of the tool. The group has also used esentutl to change file extensions to avoid detection.[6][10][11]
menuPass has used tcping.exe, similar to Ping, to probe port status on systems of interest.[7]
menuPass has encoded strings in its malware with base64 as well as with a simple, single-byte XOR obfuscation using key 0x40.[9][10]
menuPass uses PowerSploit to inject shellcode into PowerShell.[7]
menuPass has used process hollowing in iexplore.exe to load the RedLeaves implant.[9]
menuPass has used RDP connections to move across the victim network.[4][6]
menuPass has installed updates and new malware on victims.[4][6]
menuPass has used Putty Secure Copy Client (PSCP) to transfer data.[4]

menuPass uses scripts to enumerate IP ranges on the victim network. menuPass has also issued the command net view /domain to a PlugX implant to gather information about remote systems on the network.[7][5]
menuPass has used a script (atexec.py) to execute a command on a target machine via Task Scheduler.[7]
menuPass has used malicious macros embedded inside Office documents to execute files.[9][10]
menuPass has sent malicious Office documents via email as part of spearphishing campaigns as well as executables disguised as documents.[7][5][10][6]
menuPass has used several tools to scan for open NetBIOS nameservers and enumerate NetBIOS sessions.[7]
menuPass has used net use to conduct connectivity checks to machines.[4]
menuPass has used legitimate access granted to Managed Service Providers in order to access victims of interest.[7][5]
menuPass has attempted to get victims to open malicious files such as Windows Shortcuts (.lnk) and/or Microsoft Office documents, sent via email as part of spearphishing campaigns.[7][5][9][6][10]
menuPass has used valid accounts shared between Managed Service Providers and clients to move between the two environments.[4]
menuPass uses a modified version of pentesting script wmiexec.vbs, which logs into a remote machine using WMI.[7][8]
